Prefix Sets.
An element v \in W is called a prefixprefix of an element w \ in W if there exist an element v' \in W such that w = vv' and \ell(w) = \ell(v) + \ell(v'). In that case we write v \leq w. In other words, v < w if \ell(w) - \ell(v) = \ell(v^{-1} w). The prefix set of w \in W is the set \{v \in W : v < w\} of all prefixes v of w.

Weak Intervals.
The weak intervalweak interval [v, w] from v \in W to w \in W consist of all those prefixes x of w which have v as their prefix. In other words, [v, w] = \{x \in W : v \leq x \leq w\}. A prefix set is a weak interval [v,w] with v = 1. Every weak interval can be described as a translate of a prefix set, [v, w] = v [1, v^{-1} w].
